title: Prepare for release 0.3.0-rc1.
Add additional RTR target metrics.
body:
This PR adds two more metrics to the RTR target: `rtr_target_serial` with the current serial number and `rtr_target_payload_size` with the number of items in the current payload set.

Fixes #102. (Some more.)

title: Better log message if RTR unit’s connect fails.
body:
This PR improves the log message when an RTR unit fails to connect to the server.

Fixes #59.

title: Add per-client metrics to the RTR target.
body:
This PR adds per-client metrics to the RTR target. If enable for an RTR target through the new `client-metrics` config option, the target collects metrics for each unique client address encountered. These metrics are identical to those available in Routinator and include number of currently open connections, last serial number seen, last 
update, last reset and serial update, and bytes read and written.

The PR also refactors the socket handling code in the RTR target by heavily borrowing from Routinator’s implementation.

Fixes #102.

title: Upgrade hyper, reqwest, rustls.
body: This PR upgrades the hyper, reqwest, and rustls dependencies to current versions.

title: Add fuzzing for payload and fix all the issues found.
body: This PR adds fuzzing via `cargo fuzz` to the `payload` module and adds fixes for the issues that the fuzzer uncovered.

title: Additional config options for the HTTP client.
body:
This PR adds four new configuration options for the HTTP client used by the _json_ unit.

These are `http-root-certs` for additional TLS root certificates, `http-user-agent` for setting a custom user agent, `http-client-addr` to specify a local address to bind to, and `http-proxies` to add HTTP proxies. The last option is only available if the `socks` feature is enabled which it is by default.

Fixes #108.

title: Add a merge unit.
body:
This PR adds a new `merge` unit that merges the payload from all its healthy sources.

This PR replaces #66.

title: Combine payload update and setting healthy status.
body:
This PR revises how updates are dispatched. Instead of having separate status and payload updates, these are now merged into one with a payload update implying a status change to healthy. This should avoid the potential for strange races between setting the status back to healthy and updating the data. 

A resulting limitation is that if a unit wants to change from stalled to healthy it has to submit a payload update, but in practice this health status change is pretty much always triggered by a new payload update becoming available, so this should be fine.

This is a breaking change.

title: Allow configuring the timer values in the RTR targets.
body:
This PR adds three optional configuration values to the RTR target configuration that allow configuring the timer values included in an RTR exchange.

Fixes #105.

title: Fix broken example config file.
body: The config file requires IP addresses, not domain names.

title: Refactor communication to cleanly deal with start-up and shut-down.
body:
This PR changes some aspect of the communication module to deal with startup and shutdown of units.

In order to allow a unit or target that is started after an upstream unit and misses updates to gain access to the last update, a gate will store the last update and include it in its response to the subscription request. A consequence of this is that the last update of every unit will be kept around. In most cases, they need to be kept around, anyway – the _rtr_ unit needs it for diffing, the _any_ unit needs to keep the updates for all its sources so it can seamlessly switch –, so this shouldn’t have too much of an impact in practice.

The PR also fixes an issue when shutting down units. In this case, the link goes into a “gone” state. Querying the link  was immediately returning with the gone state. If the unit owning the link was looping over this link query, it would just end up in an endless, uninterrupted loop which would take over one of the threads of the Tokio runtime. This is fixed by having `Link::query` not return in case the status is “gone” but rather just remain in pending state forever.

In addition, the PR does a change the the handling of suspending a link. Earlier, querying the link would un-suspend it (or rather, that was the intention, I believe it didn’t actually do that). Now suspending and unsuspending is just a state change communicated to the gate which then can in turn report this to its unit for further consideration.

Finally, the PR adds both a test unit and a test target as well as changes the manager to allow setting up a unit graph programmatically. This way, test cases with unit graphs can be written and their behaviour asserted.

title: Add support for conditional HTTP requests.
body:
This PR adds support for conditional HTTP requests via Etags and Last-Modified to both the JSON unit and the HTTP JSON target.

Fixes #38.

title: Drops keeping serial number and diff with updates.
body:
This PR removes the serial number and optional diff from `payload::Update`.

The serial number was never actually used anywhere so has always been unnecessary. However, it did provide a sort of safety net for using the optional diff in case an update was missed somehow. This, however, only ever happened with the RTR target, so dropping the diff and re-calculating is probably acceptable both from a performance and reliability perspective.

title: Introduce daemonbase and use it for logging.
body: This PR switches the logging configuration to use the new _daemonbase_ crate.

title: Upgrade toml to 0.8.2.
body: This PR upgrades _toml_ to 0.8.2 which requires a few small changes.

title: Upgrade to Plotous v7.
Fix slurm unit start race.
body:
This PR fixes a race in the slurm unit that caused exceptions not processed if loading the files took too long. As a side-effect, the unit’s output will now be updated immediately when an update to the files has been detected rather than only be considered when the next update from the unit’s source comes in.

This fixes one part of #86.

title: Upgrade Rust edition, Rust version, and dependencies.
body:
This PR upgrades Rust to the 2021 edition and the minimal Rust version to 1.70. It also upgrades all dependencies to their latest version and fixes all resulting issue. Finally, it includes a number of Clippy-suggested code fixes.

This does not yet upgrade _toml_ since it has changed in a rather breaking way.

title: Log the changes that the Slurm unit does.
body:
This PR adds debug-level logging of what the Slurm units adds to and removes from an update.

Fixes #84.

title: Migrate to NLnetLabs reusable packaging workflow
body:
This PR replaces the current Packaging `pkg.yml` and Packaging Docker `pkg-docker.yml` workflows with a much simpler Packaging `pkg.yml` workflow  that outsources the behaviour to a new equivalent reusable workflow defined in the NLnet Labs organisation wide https://github.com/NLnetLabs/.github repository.

A successful test run against this PR branch can be seen here: https://github.com/NLnetLabs/rtrtr/actions/runs/3038246286

The test run doesn't exercise the behaviour of pushing Docker images and manifests to Docker Hub as that only happens when a release Git tag (i.e. a tag named `v*` without a `-XXX` suffix) is pushed to this Git repository, but was tested elsewhere as part of the development of the centralized reusable workflow (e.g. [here](https://github.com/NLnetLabs/.github/pull/6#issuecomment-1244335732)).

At present the RTRTR packaging workflow does cross compile but only for producing ARM architecture DEB packages, the cross compiled binaries are not used by the Docker packaging workflow. If we were to later want to produce multi-arch Docker images  the new centralized reusable workflow supports it but expects the `Dockerfile` to then take a `MODE=copy` Docker build argument. The Krill and Routinator projects already use a `Dockerfile` modified to support this, but this RTRTR repo does not have those changes and they are not part of this PR.

The centralized reusable packaging workflow (see https://github.com/NLnetLabs/.github/blob/master/.github/workflows/pkg-rust.yml) needs more documentation, but in short it is the result of combining and normalizing various fixes and improvements that were added to the Krill and Routinator workflows over time. While similar to the `pkg.yml` workflow defined in this repository prior to this PR, it is sufficiently changed so as to make a direct comparison via diff quite difficult. Changes have been made to make the workflow more generic and reusable and thus for example the set of architectures and operating systems to build for is no longer hard-coded but now passed in as a set of rules, and the scripts to run to test installed packages post install and upgrade are now stored as separate files in the repo and passed by filepath reference to the reusable workflow.

Note: This PR also modifies the way RPM scriptlets are defined because changes were needed to fix issues seen in the Krill and Routinator projects due to the limited way that the [`cargo-generate-rpm`](https://github.com/cat-in-136/cargo-generate-rpm) cargo helper command permits RPM scriptlets to be defined (i.e. they must be defined inline in TOML, they cannot be defined as references to Bash files stored separately).
